name: Black Tree Monitor
description: A smaller, slender monitor with a uniformly black-gray coloration. Juveniles have regular rows of bright yellow spots on a gray background. It has unusually long teeth suited for grasping prey.
spread_note: Indonesia – Aru Islands southwest of New Guinea
proportions: Body length 35 cm; tail length up to 95 cm
reproduction: Females lay 2–6 large leathery eggs; incubation lasts 172–240 days.
attractions: On New Guinea and surrounding islands, monitors have diversified into several distinctly colored species, currently being described by scientists. The black tree monitor is closely related to the emerald tree monitor (sometimes considered its subspecies). Like it, it can run and swim persistently and climbs trees adeptly. Its slender, prehensile tail and long limbs are excellent adaptations for life in tree canopies.
breeding: A pair of black tree monitors arrived at the zoo in 2007 from Plzeň Zoo.
